title: 115_hr883
content: The Act titled "Targeting Child Predators Act of 2017" prohibits the disclosure of administrative subpoenas. Section 3486(a) of title 18, United States Code is amended by changing references from the Secretary of the Treasury to the Secretary of Homeland Security, removing the requirement for court-ordered subpoenas, and implementing a 180-day non-disclosure period for recipients of subpoenas accompanied by a certification and notice of judicial review. The federal official issuing the subpoena certifies that disclosure may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardize an investigation. Recipients of the subpoena can disclose information to comply with the request or seek legal advice from an attorney. The subpoena recipient can disclose information to seek legal advice from an attorney or other permitted individuals. Recipients must adhere to nondisclosure requirements and notify others of such requirements if disclosing information subject to them. Upon request, recipients must inform the federal official of any intended disclosures. The nondisclosure requirement imposed under subparagraph (A) can be reviewed judicially and extended as per section 3486A. Subpoenas issued under this section must include notice of the availability of judicial review. SEC. 3. Judicial review of nondisclosure requirements. "Section 3486A allows recipients of subpoenas to request judicial review of nondisclosure requirements. The recipient can notify the Government or file a petition for review within 30 days of receiving the subpoena." The recipient of a subpoena can request judicial review of nondisclosure requirements in the district court where they are doing business or where the investigation is being conducted. The court should rule promptly on any petitions or applications filed, and the nondisclosure requirement remains in effect during related proceedings. The court should promptly rule on applications for a nondisclosure order, which must include conditions appropriate to the circumstances. An application must include a certification from the Federal official indicating potential risks if disclosure is not prohibited, such as endangering individuals, flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or jeopardizing an investigation. "A district court of the United States shall issue a nondisclosure order if disclosure of information may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, tamper with evidence, intimidate witnesses, or jeopardize an investigation or trial." The district court may issue an ex parte order extending a nondisclosure order for additional periods of 180 days or longer if necessary to prevent unauthorized disclosure of information requested under section 3486. Hearings must be closed to prevent disclosure of requests, reports, or information. Petitions, filings, records, orders, certifications, and subpoenas must be kept sealed as needed. The district court may issue an ex parte order extending a nondisclosure order for additional periods of 180 days or longer to prevent unauthorized disclosure of information requested under section 3486. Petitions, filings, records, orders, certifications, and subpoenas must be kept under seal as necessary. "3486A. Judicial review of nondisclosure requirements. Passed the House of Representatives on May 22, 2017. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk."
